ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION
PROHIBITION ORDER AGAINST MR CHAN KIAN HIN
(Reasons behind revocation)


    1. Mr J. B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Home Affairs if he will state the reasons behind the revocation within one month of the Prohibition Order against Mr Chan Kian Hin who was arrested along with Mr Abdul Razak bin Ahmad.

    The Minister of State for Home Affairs (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, Chan Kian Hin and Abdul Razak bin Ahmad were both served with Expulsion Orders on 18th November 1966 for their involvement in Communist front activities. The Government decided to revoke the order of expulsion against Chan on 10th December 1966 in view of Chan's clear

Column: 718

repentance for his past actions, and the appeals from Chan's father.

    Mr J. B. Jeyaretnam (Non-Constituency Member): As I understood from the Minister when I last raised the question, their crime was agitation for greater academic freedom and I was told that they were also creating fights. If that is the reason, why was it found possible to revoke the Order against Mr Chan just because he made an appeal and showed his repentance when the others have not had the Orders revoked?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, in our exchange in the last debate, I made it very clear that it was not just a case of students agitating just for academic freedom. They played leading roles in the organisation of demonstrations, processions and even a violent clash. This is part of the same story because, as I have mentioned just now, the communists were using the students. There was a plan to exploit the student unrest by uniting the various protest movements, intensifying illegal street processions and demonstrations and provoking a situation that would undermine law and order. These led to the formation of the students' national action front - which the Government saw, at that time, to be a dangerous development because it was dominated by left wing and pro-communist elements from the Nanyang University and the Chinese Middle Schools. Hence, the Government had to nip the situation in the bud, act decisively and four foreign students were expelled. Again, as I have said, every case must be decided on its own merits and facts. Here, Chan Kian Hin had made an individual appeal, where he had stated very clearly his repentance for his past actions and his father, who was a Singaporean, also appealed.

    If Mr Jeyaretnam is still championing the cause of Chan Kian Hin, who is now dead, and in his question, he also talked about Abdul Razak, I think we should know what interest he has got in the matter. As I said the last time, why is he championing the cause of a foreigner who has shown himself to be anti-Singapore?

Column: 719



    Mr Jeyaretnam: May I, again, remind the Minister that I am not here to answer questions. I have said this before. It is simply a matter of justice as between person and person.

    Mr Speaker: Order. Mr Jeyaretnam, what is your question? Please proceed to your question.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: He has asked me what is my interest. It is a matter of justice. I am answering him.

    Mr Speaker: Do you have any question?

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Yes, Sir.

    Mr Speaker: Ask your question, please.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: May I know from the Minister, he keeps saying about riots and fights, whether there were any riots at all during that period? Was anyone prosecuted for rioting?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, on Mr Jeyaretnam's earlier point, parliamentary time is precious. As Mr Jeyaretnam is an NCMP, he is accountable to this House and indeed to Singaporeans for the questions that he asks. He has asked very pointed questions about foreigners who had been expelled. It is right for me to ask that question. The record is very clear, Sir. If you go back to the record, you will see that those were heady days when there were student protests, demonstrations, processions involving students from the four tertiary institutions at that time. There was indeed a violent clash with the police at the City Hall.

    Mr Shriniwas Rai (Nominated Member): Mr Speaker, Sir, with your leave, may I ask the Minister of State whether any other student leader has been arrested for the last 10 years?

Column: 720

Hin also not a Malaysian at that time? He was not a Singaporean.

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, before I answer the question, perhaps Mr Jeyaretnam should also answer this point. What is his interest in the matter? Is he beholden to anybody? He has asked about the other foreigners who were also expelled. Yes, there were four of them, all foreigners, including Chan Kian Hin. But unlike Chan Kian Hin, the other three did not have families who were Singaporeans.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister keeps asking me and you say that I should not answer. May I say, again, it is a question of justice and fairness as between persons who are concerned. Why is this man singled out?

    Mr Speaker: Order. Mr Jeyaretnam, you keep repeating the same points and you are asking the same questions. Do you have any other fresh questions? If not, I propose to end this Question for Oral Answer unless you have new questions.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, with respect, he has asked me a question and I am trying to answer, and you tell me that I should not answer it. Then you should tell him, Mr Speaker, with respect, not to ask me any questions.

    Mr Speaker: I am asking you whether you have any fresh questions.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: May I ask him to answer my question whether there were any riots and whether anyone was prosecuted?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: As I said, Sir, it is all in the record, the processions, demonstrations and ---

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Could you tell us?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Yes. If Mr Jeyaretnam were to look up the press reports during that time, those indeed were heady days. And as I have said, yes, there were processions, demonstrations and there was a violent clash. There were other people who were also expelled. But

the fact that Mr Jeyaretnam keeps taking up this case, particularly Abdul Razak, that is why I have asked that question. Why not the other people who had been expelled?

ESTIMATES OF EXPENDITURE FOR THE FINANCIAL YEAR
1ST APRIL, 1999 TO 31ST MARCH, 2000


    Order read for consideration in Committee of Supply [4th Allotted Day].

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]



    Head T -

    The Chairman: Head T - Ministry of Manpower. Amendment No. (1), Mdm Foo.

    Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon (Bukit Timah) : Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head T of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100.

    On 1st April 1998, the Ministry of Labour was revamped and renamed the Ministry of Manpower (MOM). This was done to allow MOM to take on a more integrated approach in planning, developing and managing human resources and to ensure that these functions are well coordinated.

    In the years ahead, competition will intensify as the global economy becomes increasingly interlinked. In a knowledge economy, the most important resource will not be merely capital or machinery but human beings. The strategy for us to thrive in the knowledge era must be to convert our manpower into a key engine of growth.

    Hence, the first point I wish to raise is on this aspect of manpower planning. Could the Minister enlighten this House on (1) the overall manpower plans that MOM has in mind; (2) MOM's strategy for balancing supply and demand of manpower; (3) how MOM determines manpower demand; and (4) what policies and programmes will be formulated to synchronise the needs of industries for

Column: 722

skilled manpower and the needs of Singaporeans for good jobs in the growth sectors.

    Could the Minister also tell the House how the above information will be released to the public to raise awareness about job growing areas and the skills needed? We would also like to know the progress of the Manpower 21 study effort.

    Last year, for the first time in many years, we suffered a net job loss of 17,000. In the good years, the net job gain was 120,000. What would be the projections for this year?

    In the last few days, we heard a lot from our colleagues about the mismatch between employers and employees in job expectation and skills. What effort is being taken by the Employment Service Department to improve this situation?

    Because of the low rate of population growth and the rapid aging process of our society, we have had to rely on foreign workers. We also lack skills or knowledge in certain critical areas needed by industries and therefore the infusion of foreign talent is necessary. Otherwise, we will not be able to attract these high-tech industries. This means that fewer jobs will be created for Singaporeans.

    However, in a time of job loss and fewer job openings available, could the Minister elaborate on what measures are being taken to balance and manage the supply side of local and foreign workforce? During the recession, there are problems of missing foreign workers and increasing disputes between employers and foreign workers. What measures is MOM taking to tackle this problem?

    Mr Chay Wai Chuen (Tanjong Pagar): Sir, I note that the Ministry has set up a special unit called the Manpower Planning Division and the Minister knows my view on this so-called manpower approach which I have expressed in the House. I think developing human resource is a far more important area of focus for his Ministry than just manpower planning.

Column: 723



    The significant experience of most of the manpower planning agencies in the US and UK historically is that they are usually wrong in their projections. Even in our case, for decades, we have seen how regular the universities have been out in projecting within a four-year period the output of graduates.

    The other day, I was talking to a young officer from the Community Development Council and she told me that she was a graduate from the Estate Management Faculty. She told me that only one third of her cohort from that Faculty probably found jobs in the estate management, real estate or property development sector where they have been trained. The rest have to look for jobs elsewhere in other sectors. There are many other examples of civil engineers, accountants, lawyers, doctors which output from the university does not quite match the demand often times.

    The trouble with manpower planning is that at the high level, planning for manpower based on the growth of the economy is tautological. You need so many people in this area because we expect the economy to grow by so much in this sector. At the detailed level, where you try to project jobs at the industrial sector level, you can often be way out because of definition boundaries. This will be particularly so when the new knowledge economy will keep everyone guessing as to which are the sunrise and sunset sectors. In this game, the bureaucrats are not particularly the best participants. Even in the much vaunted stock and flow concept of skill/job retention and attrition, I urge caution. For example, I see in the information slides presented to Members of Parliament and resource persons, yearly inflow of 300,000 foreign labour and outflow of 260,000 for a fresh local cohort of 40,000. This seems to me to be a very large inflow and outflow figure in a year with a local cohort of 40,000.

    For years, we have been known to be the training ground for a lot of foreign workers - from maids, shipyard workers

Column: 724

or engineering sector to executives, coming here to work and then going to other countries. We should bear in mind that experience and training opportunities go with the job. When a job is denied to a Singaporean, the training and experience opportunities to them are also no more available.
12.45 pm

    The danger is that when the Government machinery gets set in, the plan will be to get in the foreign supply to satisfy the equation forecast, while our own people who could be trained, cross-trained or upgraded are in the forgotten loop or out of the loop. Finding new ways and means to train and develop our people is a more valuable effort than just bringing in from outside the members to satisfy the equation.

    I wish to add that I am not against foreign talent. My concern and experience in the private sector is that many of the so-called foreign talents here are quite foreign but not quite talent. Bringing in the numbers will deny many deserving Singaporeans the opportunity of training that goes with the job, and the numbers may well be wrong.

    Dr Wang Kai Yuen (Bukit Timah): Sir, the exchange between Dr Tan Cheng Bock, Member for Ayer Rajah and BG George Yeo, Second Minister for Trade and Industry shows that the topic of foreign talent can indeed be laden with emotion. And earlier, my colleague, Mr Chay Wai Chuen, has also pointed out the same issue. But the fact is, by and large, Singaporeans welcome immigrants to our land, especially those who can contribute to Singapore and are prepared to sink their roots here. After all, most Singaporeans are descendants of immigrants ourselves. But, as Mr Chay pointed out, this is a question that should be brought out to the open, and that is, does induction of foreign talent introduce competition to our sons and daughters? To a certain extent, I believe it does. A fair number of Singaporeans find that they do have to compete with new immigrants for jobs and housing. In certain cases, they see

Column: 725

foreign talents as taking away plum jobs as in banking and financial services, but of course, those are in small number and those people affected can take care of themselves.

    On the other cases, they see foreign professionals holding down wages in growth areas like information technology. So, obviously those affected would prefer them to be the king of the hill even though it is a small molehill. So, the affected would usually ask what is meant by the term "foreign talent". They would prefer the dictionary definition of the word "talent" as referring to people that Singapore, by itself, cannot produce and not just cannot produce in sufficient number, but cannot be produced at all. Whereas, I think the Government's definition is more like anyone who can contribute to Singapore in the designated areas.

    Let me state upfront that I support our existing foreign talent policies. In many areas where there is a shortage of people, foreign talents help in our economy. For instance, in the area of information technology, the industry is already very vibrant and the turnover too is high as it is. And in today's newspaper, we read about the story of IT professionals earning a very high income, and a lady professional who made dough in hard times would be able to buy diamonds as and when she prefers. So, even today, there are many cases of professionals changing jobs for a 20% jump in salary and after holding the job at the current salary for less than three months.

    Therefore, if we just depend on local manpower, I believe that the salary will escalate even faster and we would price ourselves out of the global market. And this is not a problem unique to Singapore. Even in the United States, with a population of 220 million, it is also unable to meet market demands by just depending on domestic supply alone. As a result, the United States is opening its market, and absorbing a high number of foreign IT professionals through increasing the quota of H1 visa in 1999. H1 is a US immigrant visa for skilled professionals.

Column: 726

I think we could say that, in the short-term, some individual Singaporeans would face greater competition from foreign immigrants. In the long-term, foreign immigrants bring greater prosperity and diversity to our country. On balance, we should welcome foreign immigrants.

    Let me move on to some of the policies implemented by the Ministry of Manpower that would affect the induction of foreign talents. I am referring to the issuance of employment pass by the Ministry of Manpower when it took over that function from the Ministry of Home Affairs. In so doing, it introduces the new classification of employment pass and I am referring to the P, Q1 and Q2. Perhaps, the Ministry believes that the new classification solves some problems in the old system but, unfortunately, it also introduces some undesirable effects.

    Firstly, many highly educated foreigners are grouped together, with skilled and semi-skilled workers in the Q2 category, primarily because their current income is not as high as they would like to have, especially in the current economic downturn. By bringing these new immigrants to our country, they have to adapt to our culture and, as such, it is not surprising that their income level tends to be lower than Singaporeans and PRs with comparable backgrounds. Some of these professionals take it as an affront to them to be lumped together with immigrants of lower educational levels. Furthermore, Q2 holders cannot bring their families to Singapore and that would make it very difficult for these foreigners to accept job offers in Singapore. As a result, some of them would ask for higher salary, just to be classified as Q1. To avoid this problem, I suggest that we go back to the principle that we determine the desirability of these foreign talents based on their educational background and their ability to contribute to Singapore on a long-term, and place less emphasis on their current income.

    The second item that I would like to bring up is that all immigrants to Singapore would like to receive their PR status as soon as possible. There are many advantages. Being a PR changes

Column: 727

the whole orientation for them. For example, they would be able to buy HDB flats in the resale market. PR status gives them a peace of mind to settle down in Singapore. On the other hand, I detect a recent, but a discernible trend of PRs leaving Singapore for greener pastures overseas. I believe one of the reasons they left Singapore is that they discovered that their income has shrunk, as a result of our CPF cut, wage restraint policy and the weakening Singapore dollar. In comparing their income on a global scale, these professionals found that they are losing out to their friends who have settled elsewhere. While their behaviour is entirely understandable, but from those Singaporeans who have interacted with them, what I would call "fair-weather PRs", they lamented that Singapore is being used as a stepping stone. They believe that perhaps we should only issue PRs to those who are really committed to Singapore. I understand that it is a very fine balance between meeting the aspirations of new immigrants through issuing them PRs and also the need to inculcate a sense of belonging to Singapore. There is no easy answer. May I seek the Minister's comment on the issues I have brought up?

    Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Sir, in times of high economic growth and full employment, I think it is fair for the Government not to impose a limit on foreign talent. In fact, in 1989, the Government formed the Immigration Affairs Committee (IMAC) with the view to bring in professionals and skilled workers from Hong Kong. The first batch of 25,000 Hongkongers were invited to work in Singapore. Can the Government let us know how many Hongkongers accepted the offer and applied for Singapore PR under that exercise?

    In March 1991, BG George Yeo, the Chairman of IMAC, in an interview, informed the Berita Harian that there was no cap on foreign talent, including Malay/Muslims who wish to come to Singapore, as long as they can contribute to the country. He said that a ceiling is only appropriate if the number turns out to be

Column: 728

too large. I would add that a ceiling should be introduced in times of high unemployment like the present time. In the past, Singapore has used the Singapore Malay Chamber of Commerce, Mendaki and the two task forces formed by IMAC to attract Malay/Muslims and Indian talents from abroad. In the case of India, advertisements for several jobs in Singapore were made from time to time, and sometimes, like Singapore Airlines, it issued their own advertisements inviting job applications.

    I would like to ask the Minister whether IMAC or other Government agencies are still actively recruiting foreign talent to Singapore. I wish to quote BG George Yeo. He said, "We cannot invite someone here and find him a job. This is not the way we work. In any case, it is not sustainable." My feedback is that foreign professionals who come here to find work sometimes are selected in preference to local applicants. It happens like this. Many foreign Caucasians are employed as managers in our local firms or positions where they are responsible for recruitment of new staff. They interview the applicants. If in a group of applicants that are interviewed happens to have Caucasians or ang mohs among them, often than not the Caucasian applications get selected. The Caucasian managers that do the selection often feel that they have the same background and culture as another Caucasian, and probably he can work better with another Caucasian than with a local. In this way, local applications for jobs can be discriminated against.

    I have known of one case where a Singaporean with an Australian mathematics degree was not selected for a teaching post in a private institution. He informed me that the interviewer was an Australian. The Australian selected a New Zealand applicant in preference to him. This Singaporean is very sore and wants this case to be brought up in Parliament. Perhaps, this may be the type of case that Dr Tan Cheng Bock had in mind when he warned against foreigners taking over jobs which rightly belong to Singaporeans. I support Dr Tan in his call to the Government to think of Singaporeans first in these hard times.

Column: 729

He does not want Singaporeans to lose out to foreigners in their applications for jobs. I do not think that Dr Tan intended to do Singapore a disservice when he made that call to the Government the other day in Parliament. I think Dr Tan realises that Singapore also needs plenty of foreign investments and he did not mean to give any wrong signals to foreigners.

    Mr Shriniwas Rai: Sir, when Dr Tan Cheng Bock spoke last week during the debate on the Prime Minister's Office, he was misunderstood, so much so that the New Paper columnist Raoul Patek made a very reasoned argument that we should not close our door to foreign talent. Singapore has always welcomed foreign talents and, in fact, it was a Dutch economist who brought us to where we are today. There are many areas which Singapore does not have the expertise and I do not think that we will have it in the near future.

    I understand Mr Chiam See Tong's plea for looking after Singapore. But we can look after Singapore better if we look at the broader economic perspective because these are people, whether in the IT sector or financial sector, who create economic prosperity, jobs and wealth for us. And I think we should not be shortsighted that in times of crisis, we should forget them. To do so would be suicidal. Let me give an example. When I was in law school, most of my teachers were foreigners. Things have changed. Now, the Law Faculty has more local lecturers than foreigners. Similarly, some years back when the Government wanted to bring foreign legal firms here, some lawyers felt that the Government was not being fair. But we have to look at it objectively. If we do not allow these foreign legal firms to be based here, the work will go to Hong Kong and elsewhere.
1.00 pm

    Sir, I would urge the Minister not to be shortsighted, but look at the broader perspective of Singapore's economic framework. After all, we are a creature of an immigrant society. Many of our forefathers came from China, India and other

Column: 730

places, and the process must continue. And if we want the process to continue, then we must send the right message to the people, because foreign capital and foreign talent are in short supply. Even America, with its huge population, is in need of talent. That is why they go to Silicon Valley from India, China and Taiwan. And if we want to create a Silicon Valley, we must have these foreign talents here. Sir, what is required is for the Ministry of Manpower to lay down a broad policy and send the message to the world at large.

    In conclusion, Sir, I do not forget my Singaporeans, because Singapore citizens and permanent residents who have been here have a stake in this country. But we should give an assurance in this House that their interests will never be sacrificed. We are bringing in these people to serve the country better. I hope when Raoul Patek reads today's debate, he will change his mind.

    Mr Yeo Guat Kwang (Cheng San)(In Mandarin): Sir, in the world today where competition is very keen, the progress and development of nations are determined more and more by the quality of its people. Therefore, the Government has taken the correct approach in emphasising on continuous and life long training and retraining for our people. We have managed to deservingly earn a reputation for having a first-rate and a world-class workforce. The challenge therefore is how we can maintain and even improve.

    In the military strategy of Sun Tze, he said the strength of an army does not depend on large forces. Rather, one must concentrate the forces. And this was taken from Sun Tze's Art of War. In my view, besides helping Singaporeans to upgrade and compete more effectively in the marketplace, we must reduce our dependence on foreign workers. While I am not belittling the contributions of foreign workers, their presence is not without any cost. I strongly urge the Ministry of Manpower to tighten its criteria and selection on the admission of foreign workers, so that not any Tom, Dick and Harry can gain employment in Singapore

Column: 731

at the expense of Singaporeans. If there are jobs that Singaporeans do not want or cannot do, then by all means foreign workers can be considered for employment. Today, in Singapore, we have more than 400,000 foreign workers and at least half of them are employed in the construction sector.

    Therefore, I would like to know if the Ministry has any plans in the pipeline to encourage the development of automation and buildable designs in the construction industry. I believe this will help to reduce our dependence on foreign workers, and also we can improve our productivity in the construction industry.

    Last year, the Ministry introduced a new work permit allocation system for the construction sector. I would like to know how effective this has been and whether there are any more control measures being planned to promote self-regulation in the construction industry.

    Throughout the years, there were reports in the newspapers about social problems we face with the vast increase in the number of foreign workers. MOM should help our employers to build proper outside dormitories and develop a comprehensive management system to address the issue of housing for foreign workers. This is something which is of great concern to our people, because if too many foreign workers live in our housing estates, it would create some social problems. With the economic downturn, many contractors have been hit by poor business, and hence face cash flow problems.
